in which Wi∗subscriptsuperscript𝑊𝑖W^{*}_{i} are local models and G∗superscript𝐺G^{*} the global model after adding noise N​(0,σi2)𝑁0subscriptsuperscript𝜎2𝑖N(0,\sigma^{2}_{i}). Equation 5 represents the fact that adding DP noise to each local model (i.e., Wi+N​(0,σi2)subscript𝑊𝑖𝑁0subscriptsuperscript𝜎2𝑖W_{i}+N(0,\sigma^{2}_{i})) is equivalent to adding an ‘aggregated’ DP noise on the global model (i.e., G+N​(0,σG2)𝐺𝑁0subscriptsuperscript𝜎2𝐺G+N(0,\sigma^{2}_{G})). More specifically, this equivalent Gaussian noise on the global model is the sum of Gaussian noise applied on each local model with a scaling factor NG=1n​Σi=1n​Nisubscript𝑁𝐺1𝑛subscriptsuperscriptΣ𝑛𝑖1subscript𝑁𝑖N_{G}=\frac{1}{n}\Sigma^{n}_{i=1}N_{i}. Here, NGsubscript𝑁𝐺N_{G} and Nisubscript𝑁𝑖N_{i} are random variables with distribution N​(0,σG2)𝑁0subscriptsuperscript𝜎2𝐺N(0,\sigma^{2}_{G}) and N​(0,σi2)𝑁0subscriptsuperscript𝜎2𝑖N(0,\sigma^{2}_{i}), respectively. As such, we can compute the equivalent noise scale for the global model:

σG2superscriptsubscript𝜎𝐺2\displaystyle\sigma_{G}^{2} =1n2​Σi=1n​σi2=(1ϵ​2​l​n​1.25δ)2⋅1n2​Σi=1n​Δi2absent1superscript𝑛2subscriptsuperscriptΣ𝑛𝑖1subscriptsuperscript𝜎2𝑖⋅superscript1italic-ϵ2𝑙𝑛1.25𝛿21superscript𝑛2subscriptsuperscriptΣ𝑛𝑖1subscriptsuperscriptΔ2𝑖\displaystyle=\frac{1}{n^{2}}\Sigma^{n}_{i=1}\sigma^{2}_{i}=(\frac{1}{\epsilon}\sqrt{2ln\frac{1.25}{\delta}})^{2}\cdot\frac{1}{n^{2}}\Sigma^{n}_{i=1}\Delta^{2}_{i}
=(1ϵ​2​l​n​1.25δ)2⋅1n2​Σi=1n​αi2​ei2.absent⋅superscript1italic-ϵ2𝑙𝑛1.25𝛿21superscript𝑛2subscriptsuperscriptΣ𝑛𝑖1subscriptsuperscript𝛼2𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝑒2𝑖\displaystyle=(\frac{1}{\epsilon}\sqrt{2ln\frac{1.25}{\delta}})^{2}\cdot\frac{1}{n^{2}}\Sigma^{n}_{i=1}\alpha^{2}_{i}e^{2}_{i}.\vspace{-1.5em} (6)

Equation 5.1 describes the relation between the DP noise added on FLAME’s global model and the DP noise added on each local model. This noise scale relation in Eq. 5.1 together with the transformation in Eq. 5 enable FLAME to provide guaranteed security for the global model against backdoors, thereby addressing Challenge C3subscript𝐶3C_{3} .

In Alg. 1, we use the median of Euclidean distances eisubscript𝑒𝑖e_{i} as the upper bound Stsubscript𝑆𝑡S_{t} to clip the admitted local models (line 9-11). We hypothesize that the sensitivity of a model Wisubscript𝑊𝑖W_{i} is positively correlated with its weight magnitude |Wi|subscript𝑊𝑖|W_{i}| (see Theorem 2 for details). In the case of linear models, the sensitivity ΔΔ\Delta has a linear relation with the model weight |w→|→𝑤|\overrightarrow{w}| (see Eq. 8). Therefore, we use the following approximation:

1n2​Σi=1n​αi2​ei2=1n2​Σi=1n​Δi2≈St2,1superscript𝑛2subscriptsuperscriptΣ𝑛𝑖1subscriptsuperscript𝛼2𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝑒2𝑖1superscript𝑛2subscriptsuperscriptΣ𝑛𝑖1subscriptsuperscriptΔ2𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝑆2𝑡\frac{1}{n^{2}}\Sigma^{n}_{i=1}\alpha^{2}_{i}e^{2}_{i}=\frac{1}{n^{2}}\Sigma^{n}_{i=1}\Delta^{2}_{i}\approx S^{2}_{t},\vspace{-0.5em}

where Stsubscript𝑆𝑡S_{t} is the weight clipping bound. Having substituted the above approximation into Eq. 5.1, we can compute the noise scale of DP that FLAME deploys on the global model NGsubscript𝑁𝐺N_{G}:

σG≈Stϵ​2​l​n​1.25δsubscript𝜎𝐺subscript𝑆𝑡italic-ϵ2𝑙𝑛1.25𝛿\sigma_{G}\approx\frac{S_{t}}{\epsilon}\sqrt{2ln\frac{1.25}{\delta}}\vspace{-0.6em} (7)

This concludes the proof of Theorem 1. ∎
FLAME’s adaptive noising step applies the Gaussian noise with the noise scale computed in Eq. 7 on the global model for backdoor elimination as shown in Alg. 1, line 13-14. Note that FLAME’s noising scheme is adaptive since the clipping bound Stsubscript𝑆𝑡S_{t} is obtained dynamically in each tt​hsuperscript𝑡𝑡ℎt^{th} epoch.

Next, we present Theorem 2 and justify how FLAME design reduces the derived noise level with step 3 (S3) below.

(S3) Clustering and clipping components in FLAME help to reduce the DP noise boundary. Recall that FLAME protects the FL system against backdoor attacks using three steps: clustering, clipping, and adding DP noise. The overall workflow of FLAME is shown in Fig. 4. If multiple backdoors exist in the FL system, the first two steps (clustering and clipping) can remove a subset of backdoors as shown in Fig. 3a. Note that the remaining backdoors are ‘closer’ to the benign model updates in terms of both magnitude and direction. This gives us the intuition that removing the remaining backdoors by adding DP noise becomes easier (i.e., the noise scale σGsubscript𝜎𝐺\sigma_{G} is smaller) after the first two steps of FLAME.

We can see from Theorem 1 that the Gaussian noise scale σ𝜎\sigma required for backdoor resilience increases with the sensitivity of each local model ΔisubscriptΔ𝑖\Delta_{i}. We describe two characteristics of the model parameter W𝑊W, i.e., direction and magnitude in §4. We discuss how these two factors impact the sensitivity of the model defined in Eq. 4 below.

Theorem 2.

Backdoor models with large angular deviation from benign ones, or with large parameter magnitudes have high sensitivity values ΔΔ\Delta.

Proving DP-based backdoor security for DNN models is still an open problem, even in the centralized setting. We, therefore, adopt a common approach in literature (e.g., [19]) by providing theoretical proof for linear models and validating it for DNNs empirically.

Proof: for a linear model f𝑓f where the function output is determined by the inner product of model weight vector w→→𝑤\overrightarrow{w} and the data vector x→→𝑥\overrightarrow{x}, we have

f​(w;x)=w→⋅x→=|w|⋅|x|⋅c​o​s​θ,𝑓𝑤𝑥⋅→𝑤→𝑥⋅𝑤𝑥𝑐𝑜𝑠𝜃f(w;~{}x)=\overrightarrow{w}\cdot\overrightarrow{x}=|w|\cdot|x|\cdot cos\theta,\vspace{-0.5em} (8)

where θ=<w→,x→>\theta=<\overrightarrow{w},\overrightarrow{x}> is the angle between two vectors. In this case, it is straightforward to see that if the backdoor attack changes the parameter magnitude |w|𝑤|w| or the direction θ𝜃\theta of the model f𝑓f, the resulting poisoned model f′superscript𝑓′f^{\prime} has a large sensitivity value based on the definition in Eq. 4. ∎

This analysis suggests that backdoor models with large angular deviations or with large weight magnitudes have a high sensitivity value ΔΔ\Delta. Recall that FLAME deploys dynamic clustering (§4.3.1) to remove poisoned models with large cosine distances, and employs adaptive clipping (§4.3.2) to remove poisoned models with large magnitudes. Therefore, the sensitivity of the remaining backdoor models is lower compared to the one before applying these two steps. As a result, FLAME can use a small Gaussian noise to eliminate the remaining backdoors after applying clustering and clipping, which is beneficial for preserving the main task accuracy.

We empirically show how the noise scale for backdoor elimination changes after applying each step of FLAME. Particularly, we measure the smallest Gaussian noise scale σ𝜎\sigma required to defeat all backdoors (i.e., B​A=0%𝐵𝐴percent0BA=0\%) in three settings: i) No defense components applied (which is equivalent to the previous DP-based defense [20, 9]); ii) After applying dynamic clustering; iii) After applying both dynamic clustering and adaptive clipping (which is the setting of FLAME). We conduct this comparison experiment on the IoT-Traffic dataset (cf. §6). For each communication round, 100 clients are selected where k=40𝑘40k=40 are adversaries. We remove the backdoor by adding Gaussian noise N​(0,σ2)𝑁0superscript𝜎2{N}(0,\sigma^{2}) to the aggregated model. Table 1 summarizes the evaluation results in the above three settings. We can observe from the comparison results that the noise scale required to eliminate backdoors decreases after individual deployment of clustering and clipping. This corroborates the correctness of Theorem 2.

5.2 Attack and Data Distribution Assumption

In FLAME, we do not make specific assumptions about the attack and data distribution compared to the existing clustering-based defenses. Let X=(X1,…,Xb)𝑋subscript𝑋1…subscript𝑋𝑏X=(X_{1},\ldots,X_{b}) be a set of distributions of benign models (W1,…,Wn−k)subscript𝑊1…subscript𝑊𝑛𝑘(W_{1},\ldots,W_{n-k}) where b≤n−k𝑏𝑛𝑘b\leq n-k. The deviation in X𝑋X is caused by the diversity of the data. Let X′=(X1′,…,Xa′)superscript𝑋′subscriptsuperscript𝑋′1…subscriptsuperscript𝑋′𝑎X^{\prime}=(X^{\prime}_{1},\ldots,X^{\prime}_{a}) be a set of distributions of poisoned models (W1′,…,Wk′)subscriptsuperscript𝑊′1…subscriptsuperscript𝑊′𝑘(W^{\prime}_{1},\ldots,W^{\prime}_{k}) where a≤k𝑎𝑘a\leq k. The deviation in X′superscript𝑋′X^{\prime} is caused by the diversity of the benign data and backdoors (e.g., poisoned data or model crafting). Existing works assume that Xi′≈Xj′(∀i,j:1≤i,j≤a)X^{\prime}_{i}\approx X^{\prime}_{j}\quad(\forall i,j:1\leq i,j\leq a) (see e.g., [25] or X′≠Xsuperscript𝑋′𝑋X^{\prime}\neq X [56, 11]). However, this assumption does not hold in many situations because (i) there can be one or multiple attackers injecting multiple backdoors [9], or (ii) the adversary can inject one or several random (honeypot) models having a distribution Xr′subscriptsuperscript𝑋′𝑟X^{\prime}_{r} that is significantly different from X∪(X′∖Xr′)𝑋superscript𝑋′subscriptsuperscript𝑋′𝑟X\cup(X^{\prime}\setminus X^{\prime}_{r}), and (iii) the adversary can control how much the backdoored models deviate from benign ones as discussed in §3. Therefore, approaches that purely divide models into two groups, e.g., K-means [56] will incorrectly classify models having distribution Xr′subscriptsuperscript𝑋′𝑟X^{\prime}_{r} into the malicious group and all remaining models (having distributions drawn from (X∪(X′∖Xr′)𝑋superscript𝑋′subscriptsuperscript𝑋′𝑟X\cup(X^{\prime}\setminus X^{\prime}_{r})) into the benign group. As a result, all backdoored models having distributions drawn from (X′∖Xr′superscript𝑋′subscriptsuperscript𝑋′𝑟X^{\prime}\setminus X^{\prime}_{r}) are classified as benign, as demonstrated in Fig. 5b. In contrast, FLAME does not rely on such specific assumptions (the adversary can arbitrarily choose X′superscript𝑋′X^{\prime}). If the distribution Xi′subscriptsuperscript𝑋′𝑖X^{\prime}_{i} of a poisoned model is similar to benign distributions in X𝑋X, FLAME will falsely classify Xi′subscriptsuperscript𝑋′𝑖X^{\prime}_{i} as being. But if the distribution Xj′subscriptsuperscript𝑋′𝑗X^{\prime}_{j} of a poisoned model is different from the distributions in X𝑋X, FLAME will identify Xj′subscriptsuperscript𝑋′𝑗X^{\prime}_{j} as an outlier and classify the associated model as malicious. To identify deviating and thus potentially malicious models, FLAME leverages the HDBSCAN algorithm to identify regions of high density in the model space. Any models that are not located in the dense regions will be categorized as outliers, as shown in Fig. 5d. As discussed in §3, FLAME aims to remove models with distributions Xj′subscriptsuperscript𝑋′𝑗X^{\prime}_{j} that have a higher attack impact compared to models with distribution Xi′subscriptsuperscript𝑋′𝑖X^{\prime}_{i}. It is worth noting, however, that the impact of such remaining backdoored models will be eliminated by the noising component as shown in §5.1

Striking a balance between accuracy and security: Clustering and DP-based approaches affect model accuracy as discussed in §4.2 (Challenges C2subscript𝐶2C_{2} and C3subscript𝐶3C_{3}). In particular, an approach that aims to maximize the number of filtered malicious models may lead to many false positives, i.e., many benign models being filtered out. Moreover, applying a very low clipping bound or a very high level of injected noise will degrade model accuracy. To address these problems, FLAME is configured so that the clustering component removes only models with high attack impact rather than all malicious models, i.e., it aims to remove the first backdoor type W1′subscriptsuperscript𝑊′1W^{\prime}_{1} as shown in Fig. 3. In addition, FLAME carefully estimates the clipping bound and noise level to ensure backdoor elimination while preserving model performance. As discussed in §4.3.2, the L2-norms of model updates depend on the number of training rounds, dataset types, and type of backdoors. Consequently, the clipping threshold and noise level should be adapted to L2-norms. We therefore apply the median of the L2-norms of model updates as the clipping bound Stsubscript𝑆𝑡S_{t} (cf. Lines 9-11 of Alg. 1). This ensures that Stsubscript𝑆𝑡S_{t} is always computed between a benign local model and the global model since we assume that more than 50% of clients are benign (cf. §2.3). Further, estimating noise level based on Stsubscript𝑆𝑡S_{t} (cf. Lines 13-14 of Alg. 1) also provides a noise boundary that ensures that the global model is resilient against backdoors as discussed in §5.1. Moreover, our comparison of potential values for Stsubscript𝑆𝑡S_{t} presented in §B.2 and §B.3 shows that the chosen clipping bound and noise level provide the best balance between accuracy and security, i.e., FLAME eliminates backdoor while retaining the global model’s performance on the main task.

6 Experimental Setup

We conduct all the experiments using the PyTorch deep learning framework [3] and use the source code provided by Bagdasaryan et al. [9], Xie et al. [64] and Wang et al. [62] to implement the attacks. We reimplemented existing defenses to compare them with FLAME.

Datasets and Learning Configurations. Following recent research on poisoning attacks on FL, we evaluate FLAME in three typical application scenarios: word prediction [43, 42, 44, 39], image classification [54, 55, 15], and an IoT intrusion detection [48, 52, 53, 59] as summarized in Tab. 6. Verification of the effectiveness of FLAME against state-of-the-art attacks in comparison to existing defenses (cf. Tab. 2 and Tab. 3) are conducted on these three datasets in the mentioned application scenarios. Experiments for evaluating specific performance aspects of FLAME are performed on the IoT dataset as it represents a very diverse and real-world setting with clear security implications.

Evaluation Metrics. We consider a set of metrics for evaluating the effectiveness of backdoor attack and defense techniques as follows:
BA - Backdoor Accuracy indicates the accuracy of the model in the backdoor task, i.e., it is the fraction of the trigger set for which the model provides the wrong outputs as chosen by the adversary. The adversary aims to maximize 𝐵𝐴𝐵𝐴\mathit{BA}, while an effective defense prevents the adversary from increasing it.
MA - Main Task Accuracy indicates the accuracy of a model in its main (benign) task. It denotes the fraction of benign inputs for which the system provides correct predictions. The adversary aims at minimizing the effect on 𝑀𝐴𝑀𝐴\mathit{MA} to reduce the chance of being detected. The defense system should not negatively impact 𝑀𝐴𝑀𝐴\mathit{MA}.
TPR - True Positive Rate indicates how well the defense identifies poisoned models, i.e., the ratio of the number of models correctly classified as poisoned (True Positives - TP) to the total number of models being classified as poisoned: 𝑇𝑃𝑅=T​PT​P+F​P𝑇𝑃𝑅𝑇𝑃𝑇𝑃𝐹𝑃\mbox{$\mathit{TPR}$}=\frac{TP}{TP+FP}, where FP is False Positives indicating the number of benign clients that are wrongly classified as malicious. TNR - True Negative Rate indicates the ratio of the number of models correctly classified as benign (True Negatives - TN) to the total number of benign models: 𝑇𝑁𝑅=T​NT​N+F​N𝑇𝑁𝑅𝑇𝑁𝑇𝑁𝐹𝑁\mbox{$\mathit{TNR}$}=\frac{TN}{TN+FN}, where FN is False Negatives indicating the number of malicious clients that are wrongly classified as benign.

7 Experimental Results

In this section, we evaluate FLAME against backdoor attacks in the literature (§7.1) and demonstrate that our defense mechanism is resilient to adaptive attacks (§7.2). In addition, we show the effectiveness of each of FLAME’s components in §B and FLAME overhead in §D. Finally, we evaluate the impact of the number of clients (§7.3) as well as the degree of non-IID data (§7.4).

7.1 Preventing Backdoor Attacks

Effectiveness of FLAME. We evaluate FLAME against the state-of-the-art backdoor attacks called constrain-and-scale [9], DBA [64], PGD and Edge-Case [62] and an untargeted poisoning attack [22] (cf. §F) using the same attack settings as in the original works with multiple datasets. The results are shown in Tab. 2. FLAME completely mitigates the constrain-and-scale attack (𝐵𝐴=0%𝐵𝐴percent0\mbox{$\mathit{BA}$}=0\%) for all datasets. Moreover, our defense does not affect the Main Task Accuracy (𝑀𝐴𝑀𝐴\mathit{MA}) of the system as MA reduces by less than 0.4%percent0.40.4\% in all experiments. The DBA attack as well as the Edge-Case attack [62] are also successfully mitigated (𝐵𝐴=3.2%/4.0%𝐵𝐴percent3.2percent4.0\mbox{$\mathit{BA}$}=3.2\%/4.0\%). Further, FLAME is also effective against PGD attacks (𝐵𝐴=0.5%𝐵𝐴percent0.5\mbox{$\mathit{BA}$}=0.5~{}\%). It should be noted that suggesting words is a quite challenging task, causing the MA even without attack to be only 22.7%, aligned with previous work [9].

We extend our evaluation to various backdoors on three datasets. For NIDS, we evaluate 13 different backdoors (Mirai malware attacks) and 24 device types (78 IoT devices). The results show that FLAME is able to mitigate all backdoor attacks completely while achieving a high MA=99.8%. We evaluate 5 different word backdoors for WP, and 90 different image backdoors for IC, which change the output of a whole class to another class. In all cases, FLAME successfully mitigates the attack while still preserving the 𝑀𝐴𝑀𝐴\mathit{MA}.

Comparison to existing defenses. We compare FLAME to existing defenses: Krum [11], FoolsGold [25], Auror [56], Adaptive Federated Averaging (AFA) [46], Median [67] and a generalized differential privacy (DP) approach [9, 44]. Tab. 3 shows that FLAME is effective for all 3 datasets, while previous works either fail to mitigate backdoors or reduce the main task accuracy. Krum, FoolsGold, Auror, and AFA do not effectively remove poisoned models and 𝐵𝐴𝐵𝐴\mathit{BA} often remains at 100%percent100100\%. Also, some defenses make the attack even more successful than without defense. Since they remove many benign updates (cf. §B) but fail to remove a sufficient number of poisoned updates, these defenses increase the 𝑃𝑀𝑅𝑃𝑀𝑅\mathit{PMR} and, therefore, also the impact of the attack. Some defenses, e.g., Krum [11], Auror [56] or AFA [46] are not able to handle non-iid data scenarios like Reddit. In contrast, FoolsGold is only effective on the Reddit dataset (𝑇𝑃𝑅=100%𝑇𝑃𝑅percent100\mbox{$\mathit{TPR}$}=100\%) because it works well on highly non-independent and identically distributed (non-IID) data (cf. §9). Similarly, AFA only mitigates backdoors on the CIFAR-10 dataset since the data are highly IID (each client is assigned a random set of images) such that the benign models share similar distances to the global model (cf. §9). Additionally, the model’s 𝑀𝐴𝑀𝐴\mathit{MA} is negatively impacted.
The DP-based defense is effective, but it significantly reduces 𝑀𝐴𝑀𝐴\mathit{MA}. For example, it performs best on the CIFAR-10 dataset with 𝐵𝐴=0𝐵𝐴0\mbox{$\mathit{BA}$}=0, but 𝑀𝐴𝑀𝐴\mathit{MA} decreases to 78.9%percent78.978.9\% while FLAME increases 𝑀𝐴𝑀𝐴\mathit{MA} to 91.9%percent91.991.9\% which is close to the benign setting (no attacks), where 𝑀𝐴=92.2%𝑀𝐴percent92.2\mbox{$\mathit{MA}$}=92.2\%.

Effectiveness of FLAME’s Components. Further, we have also conducted an extensive evaluation of the effectiveness of each of FLAME’s components. Due to space limitations, we would like to refer to §B for the details.

7.2 Resilience to Adaptive Attacks

Given sufficient knowledge about FLAME, an adversary may seek to use adaptive attacks to bypass the defense components. In this section, we analyze such attack scenarios and strategies including changing the injection strategy, model alignment, and model obfuscation.

Changing the Injection Strategy. The adversary 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} may attempt to inject several backdoors simultaneously to execute different attacks on the system in parallel or to circumvent the clustering defense (cf. §2.2). FLAME is also effective against such attacks (cf. Fig. 5). To further investigate the resilience of FLAME against such attacks, we conduct two experiments: 1) assigning different backdoors to malicious clients and 2) letting each malicious client inject several backdoors. To ensure that each backdoor is injected by a sufficient number of clients, we increased the PMR for this experiment. We conducted these experiments with n=100𝑛100n=100 clients of which k=40𝑘40k=40 are malicious on the IoT-Traffic dataset with each type of Mirai attack representing a backdoor. First, we evaluate FLAME for 0,1,20120,1,2, 444, and 888 backdoors, meaning that the number of malicious clients for each backdoor is 0,40,20,10,04020100,40,20,10, and 555. Our experimental results show that our approach is effective in mitigating the attacks as 𝐵𝐴=0%±0.0%𝐵𝐴plus-or-minuspercent0percent0.0\mbox{$\mathit{BA}$}=0\%\pm 0.0\% in all cases, with 𝑇𝑃𝑅=95.2%±0.0%𝑇𝑃𝑅plus-or-minuspercent95.2percent0.0\mbox{$\mathit{TPR}$}=95.2\%\pm 0.0\%, and 𝑇𝑁𝑅=100.0%±0.0%𝑇𝑁𝑅plus-or-minuspercent100.0percent0.0\mbox{$\mathit{TNR}$}=100.0\%\pm 0.0\%. For the second experiment, 4 backdoors are injected by each of the 40 malicious clients. Also, in this case, the results show that FLAME can completely mitigate the backdoors.

Model Alignment. Using the same attack parameter values, i.e., 𝑃𝐷𝑅𝑃𝐷𝑅\mathit{PDR} (cf. §2.2), for all malicious clients can result in high distances between benign and poisoned models. Those high distances can be illustrated as a gap between poisoned and benign models, s.t. the clustering can separate them. Therefore, a sophisticated adversary can generate models that bridge the gap between them such that they are merged to the same cluster in our clustering. We evaluate this attack on the IoT-Traffic dataset for k=80𝑘80k=80 malicious clients and n=200𝑛200n=200 clients in total. To remove the gap, each malicious client is assigned a random amount of malicious data, i.e., a random 𝑃𝐷𝑅𝑃𝐷𝑅\mathit{PDR} ranging from 5%percent55\% to 20%percent2020\%. As Tab. 4 shows, when we apply model filtering only, our clustering component cannot identify the malicious clients well (𝑇𝑃𝑅=0%𝑇𝑃𝑅percent0\mbox{$\mathit{TPR}$}=0\%), resulting in B​A=100%𝐵𝐴percent100BA=100\%. However, when we apply FLAME, although 𝑇𝑃𝑅𝑇𝑃𝑅\mathit{TPR} remains low (5.68%percent5.685.68\%) FLAME still mitigates the attack successfully (𝐵𝐴𝐵𝐴\mathit{BA} reduces from 100%percent100100\% to 0%percent00\%). This can be explained by the fact that when the adversary 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} tunes malicious updates to be close to the benign ones, the attack’s impact is reduced and consequently averaged out by our noising component.

Model Obfuscation. 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} can add noise to the poisoned models to make them difficult to detect. However, our evaluation of such an attack on the IoT-Traffic dataset shows that this strategy is not effective. We evaluate different noise levels to determine a suitable standard deviation for the noise. Thereby, we observe that a noise level of 0.0340.0340.034 causes the models’ cosine distances in clustering to change without significantly impacting 𝐵𝐴𝐵𝐴\mathit{BA}. However, FLAME can still efficiently defend this attack: 𝐵𝐴𝐵𝐴\mathit{BA} remains at 0%percent00\% and 𝑀𝐴𝑀𝐴\mathit{MA} at 100%.

7.3 Effect of Number of Clients

Impact of Number of Malicious Clients. We assume that the number of benign clients is more than half of all clients (cf. §2.2) and our clustering is only expected to be successful when 𝑃𝑀𝑅=kn<50%𝑃𝑀𝑅𝑘𝑛percent50\mbox{$\mathit{PMR}$}=\frac{k}{n}<50\% (cf. §4.3.1). We evaluate FLAME for different 𝑃𝑀𝑅𝑃𝑀𝑅\mathit{PMR} values. Figure 7 shows how 𝐵𝐴𝐵𝐴\mathit{BA}, 𝑇𝑃𝑅𝑇𝑃𝑅\mathit{TPR}, and 𝑇𝑁𝑅𝑇𝑁𝑅\mathit{TNR} change in the IC, NIDS, and WP applications for 𝑃𝑀𝑅𝑃𝑀𝑅\mathit{PMR} values from 25%percent2525\% to 60%percent6060\%. It shows that FLAME is only effective if 𝑃𝑀𝑅<50%𝑃𝑀𝑅percent50\mbox{$\mathit{PMR}$}<50\% so that only benign clients are admitted to the model aggregation (𝑇𝑁𝑅=100%𝑇𝑁𝑅percent100\mbox{$\mathit{TNR}$}=100\%) and thus 𝐵𝐴=0%𝐵𝐴percent0\mbox{$\mathit{BA}$}=0\%. However, if 𝑃𝑀𝑅>50%𝑃𝑀𝑅percent50\mbox{$\mathit{PMR}$}>50\%, FLAME fails to mitigate the attack because the majority of poisoned models will be included resulting in low 𝑇𝑁𝑅𝑇𝑁𝑅\mathit{TNR}. Interestingly, FLAME accepted all models for 𝑃𝑀𝑅=50%𝑃𝑀𝑅percent50\mbox{$\mathit{PMR}$}=50\% (𝑇𝑃𝑅=0%𝑇𝑃𝑅percent0\mbox{$\mathit{TPR}$}=0\% and 𝑇𝑁𝑅=100%𝑇𝑁𝑅percent100\mbox{$\mathit{TNR}$}=100\%). For the IC application, since the IC data are non-IID, poisoned models are not similar. Therefore, some poisoned models were excluded from the cluster resulting in a high 𝑇𝑃𝑅𝑇𝑃𝑅\mathit{TPR} even for 𝑃𝑀𝑅𝑠𝑃𝑀𝑅𝑠\mathit{PMRs} higher than 50%. However, the majority of poisoned models were selected resulting in the drop in the 𝑇𝑁𝑅𝑇𝑁𝑅\mathit{TNR}.

Varying number of clients in different training rounds. In general, FLAME is a round-independent defense, i.e., it does not use information from previous rounds such as which clients were excluded in which rounds. Therefore, FLAME will not be affected if the number of clients or number of malicious clients varies as long as the majority of clients remain benign. To demonstrate this, we simulate realistic scenarios in which clients can join and drop out dynamically. We conducted an experiment where during each round, the total number of available clients is randomly selected. As the result, the number of malicious clients will also be random. In this experiment, we used a population of 100 clients in total, out of which 25 are malicious. In each round, a random number (from 60 to 90) of clients are selected, so that the fraction of malicious clients (𝑃𝑀𝑅𝑃𝑀𝑅\mathit{PMR}) varies in each round. Figure 8 shows the experimental results. One can see that the proportion of malicious clients (𝑃𝑀𝑅𝑃𝑀𝑅\mathit{PMR}) does not affect the effectiveness of FLAME, i.e., the backdoor is completely removed (B​A=0%𝐵𝐴percent0BA=0\%) in every round. Since all poisoned models are detected, their negative effect on the aggregated model is removed. Therefore, the MA with FLAME is better than the one without defense, and is almost always 100 % aligned with the results in Tab. 3.

7.4 Impact of the Degree of non-IID Data

Since clustering is based on measuring differences between benign and malicious updates, the distribution of data among clients might affect our defense. We conduct two experiments for both Constrain-and-scale and Edge-Case PGD on the CIFAR-10 dataset. For Reddit and IoT datasets, changing the degree of non-IID data is not meaningful since the data have a natural distribution as every client obtains data from different Reddit users or traffic chunks from different IoT devices. Following previous works [22, 62], we vary the degree of non-IID data DegnIIDsubscriptDegnIID\text{Deg}_{\text{nIID}}by changing the fraction of images belonging to a specific class assigned to clients. In particular, we divide the clients into 10 groups corresponding to the 10 classes of CIFAR-10. The clients of each group are assigned a fixed fraction of DegnIIDsubscriptDegnIID\text{Deg}_{\text{nIID}}of the images from its designated image class, while the rest of the images will be assigned to it at random. Consequently, the data distribution is random, i.e., completely IID if DegnIID=0%subscriptDegnIIDpercent0\text{Deg}_{\text{nIID}}=0\% (all images are randomly assigned) and completely non-IID if DegnIID=100%subscriptDegnIIDpercent100\text{Deg}_{\text{nIID}}=100\% (a client only gets images from its designated class).

Figure 9a shows the evaluation results for the constrain-and-scale attacks. Although FLAME does not detect the poisoned models for very non-IID scenarios, it still mitigates the attack as the BA remains 0%percent00\% for all values of DegnIIDsubscriptDegnIID\text{Deg}_{\text{nIID}}. For low DegnIIDsubscriptDegnIID\text{Deg}_{\text{nIID}}, FLAME effectively identifies the poisoned models (T​N​R=100%𝑇𝑁𝑅percent100TNR=100\%) and the MA remains on almost the same level as without defense. As shown in Fig. 9b, FLAME also mitigates the Edge-Case PGD attack effectively for all α𝛼\alpha values of the Dirichlet distribution and the MA also stays on the same level as without defense. However, since not all poisoned models are detected, a higher σ𝜎\sigma is determined dynamically to mitigate the constrain-and-scale backdoor, resulting in a slightly reduced MA for DegnIID≥0.7subscriptDegnIID0.7\text{Deg}_{\text{nIID}}\geq 0.7 (MA is 91.9%percent91.991.9\% for DegnIID=0.6subscriptDegnIID0.6\text{Deg}_{\text{nIID}}=0.6, and is reduced to 91.0%percent91.091.0\% for DegnIID=1.0subscriptDegnIID1.0\text{Deg}_{\text{nIID}}=1.0). Note that Fig. 9 shows the evaluation results in a training round t𝑡t where the global model Gtsubscript𝐺𝑡G_{t} is close to convergence [9], thus even though the TNR decreases with a large value of DegnIIDsubscriptDegnIID\text{Deg}_{\text{nIID}}, the drop of MA with FLAME is not substantial.

8 Privacy-preserving Federated Learning

A number of attacks on FL have been proposed that aim to infer from parameters of a model the presence of a specific training sample in the training dataset (membership inference attacks) [51, 57, 45], properties of training samples (property inference attacks) [26, 45], try to assess the proportion of samples of a specific class in the data (distribution estimation attacks) [63]. Inference attacks by the aggregator 𝒜ssuperscript𝒜𝑠\mathcal{A}^{s} are significantly stronger, as 𝒜ssuperscript𝒜𝑠\mathcal{A}^{s} has access to the local models [47] and can also link gained information to a specific user, while the global model anonymizes the individual contributions. Therefore, enhanced privacy protection for FL is needed that prohibits access to the local model updates.

Adversary Model (privacy). In this adversary type, 𝒜ssuperscript𝒜𝑠{\mathcal{A}^{s}} attempts to infer sensitive information about clients’ data Disubscript𝐷𝑖D_{i} from their model updates Wisubscript𝑊𝑖W_{i} [51, 57, 26, 45] by maximizing the information ϕi=Infer​(Wi)subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑖Infersubscript𝑊𝑖\phi_{i}=\textsc{Infer}(W_{i}) that 𝒜ssuperscript𝒜𝑠{\mathcal{A}^{s}} gains about the data Disubscript𝐷𝑖D_{i} of client i𝑖i by inferring from its corresponding model Wisubscript𝑊𝑖W_{i}.

Deficiencies of existing defenses. Generally, there are two approaches to protect the privacy of clients’ data: differential privacy (DP; [20]) and cryptographic techniques such as homomorphic encryption [27] or multi-party computation [16]. DP is a statistical approach that can be efficiently implemented, but it can only offer high privacy protection at the cost of a significant loss in accuracy due to the noise added to the models [68, 8]. In contrast, cryptographic techniques provide strong privacy guarantees as well as high accuracy at the cost of reduced efficiency.

Private FLAME. To securely implement FLAME using STPC, we use an optimized combination of three prominent STPC techniques as implemented with state-of-the-art optimizations in the ABY framework [16]. Fig. 10 shows an overview of private FLAME. It involves n𝑛n clients and two non-colluding servers, called aggregator A𝐴A and external server B𝐵B. Each client i∈{1,…,n}𝑖1…𝑛i\in\{1,...,n\} splits the parameters of its local update Wisubscript𝑊𝑖W_{i} into two Arithmetic shares ⟨X⟩iAsubscriptsuperscriptdelimited-⟨⟩𝑋𝐴𝑖\langle X\rangle^{A}_{i} and ⟨X⟩iBsubscriptsuperscriptdelimited-⟨⟩𝑋𝐵𝑖\langle X\rangle^{B}_{i}, such that Wi=⟨X⟩iA+⟨X⟩iBsubscript𝑊𝑖superscriptsubscriptdelimited-⟨⟩𝑋𝑖𝐴superscriptsubscriptdelimited-⟨⟩𝑋𝑖𝐵W_{i}=\langle X\rangle_{i}^{A}+\langle X\rangle_{i}^{B}, and sends ⟨X⟩iAsuperscriptsubscriptdelimited-⟨⟩𝑋𝑖𝐴\langle X\rangle_{i}^{A} to A𝐴A and ⟨X⟩iBsuperscriptsubscriptdelimited-⟨⟩𝑋𝑖𝐵\langle X\rangle_{i}^{B} to B𝐵B. A𝐴A and B𝐵B then privately compute the new global model via STPC. We co-design the distance calculation, clustering, adaptive clipping, and aggregation of FLAME (cf. Alg. 1) of FLAME as efficient STPC protocols.To further improve performance, we approximate HDBSCAN with the simpler DBSCAN [12] to avoid the construction of the minimal spanning tree in HDBSCAN as it is very expensive to realize with STPC. See §G for more details on private FLAME evaluation of its accuracy and performance.

9 Related Work

In general, existing backdoor defenses can roughly be divided into two main categories. The first one aims to distinguish malicious updates and benign updates by 1) clustering model updates [56, 25, 11, 17, 37, 32, 38], 2) changing aggregation rules [67, 28], and 3) using root dataset [6]. The second category is based on differential privacy techniques [61, 9]. Next, we will discuss these points in detail.

Clustering model updates. Several backdoor defenses, such as Krum [11], AFA [46], and Auror [56], aim at separating benign and malicious model updates. However, they only work under specific assumptions about the underlying data distributions, e.g., Auror and Krum assume that data of benign clients are iid. In contrast, FoolsGold and AFA [46] assume that benign data are non-iid. In addition, FoolsGold assumes that manipulated data are iid. As a result, these defenses are only effective under specific circumstances (cf. §7.1) and cannot handle the simultaneous injection of multiple backdoors (cf. §4.3.1). Moreover, such defenses cannot detect stealthy attacks, e.g., where the adversary constrains their poisoned updates within benign update distribution such as Constrain-and-scale attacks [9]. In contrast, FLAME does not make any assumption about the data distribution, clipping, and noising components can also mitigate stealthy attacks, and FLAME can defend against injection of multiple backdoors (cf. §4.3.1).

Changing aggregation rules. Instead of using FedAvg [42], Yin et al. [67] and Guerraoui et al. [28] propose using the median parameters from all local models as the global model parameters, i.e., Gt=Median​(W1t,…,Wnt)subscript𝐺𝑡Mediansubscriptsuperscript𝑊𝑡1…subscriptsuperscript𝑊𝑡𝑛G_{t}=\textsc{Median}(W^{t}_{1},\ldots,W^{t}_{n}). However, the adversary can bypass it by injecting stealthy models like W3′subscriptsuperscript𝑊′3W^{\prime}_{3} (cf. Fig. 2), in which the parameters of the poisoned model will be selected to be incorporated into the global model. Further, our evaluation in §7.1 shows that Median also reduces the performance of the model significantly.

Using root data. Although FLTrust [14] can defend against byzantine clients (with arbitrary behavior) and detect poisoning attacks, including backdoors, it requires the aggregator to have access to a benign root dataset. Baffle [6] utilizes clients using their own data to evaluate the performance of the aggregated model to detect backdoors. However, this approach has several limitations. Firstly, the backdoor triggers are only known to the attacker. One cannot ensure that the benign clients would have such trigger data to activate the backdoor. Secondly, Baffle does not work in a non-IID data scenario with a small number of clients as clients cannot distinguish deficits in model performance due to the backdoor from lack of data.

Differential Privacy-based approaches. Clipping and noising are known techniques to achieve differential privacy (DP) [20]. However, directly applying these techniques to defend against backdoor attacks is not effective because they significantly decrease the Main Task Accuracy (§7.1) [9]. FLAME tackles this by i) identifying and filtering out potential poisoned models that have a high attack impact (cf. §4.3.1), and ii) eliminating the residual poison with an appropriate adaptive clipping bound and noise level, such that the Main Task Accuracy is retained (cf. §4.3.2).

10 Revisiting Attacks Claiming to Bypass FLAME

Since we presented our FLAME paper at the USENIX Security Conference in 2022 [49], it has sparked considerable interest among researchers, garnering over 100 citations according to Google Scholar [1]. When creating this document, two attacks have been highlighted that allege to circumvent FLAME [36, 65]. We promptly responded by conducting an exhaustive investigation into these attacks, uncovering notable errors in their approach. They made misleading claims and seemed to misinterpret FLAME’s core design principles. To resolve this issue, we initiated a dialogue with the respective authors, leading to an acknowledgment and ensuing correction of assertions by Xu et al. [65]. In the subsequent sections, we explore these studies in greater detail.

Xu et al. [65] propose a distributed backdoor attack (DBA) targeting federated Graph Neural Networks (GNN) training. The authors assert their proposed attacks can circumvent FLAME [49]. However, upon discussing this with the authors of [65], it becomes clear that they have misinterpreted our approach and failed to incorporate all key components of FLAME in their understanding. Specifically, they have only accounted for the clustering aspect of FLAME while neglecting the Adaptive Clipping and Noising components, both of which are essential for backdoor mitigation. Acknowledging this, the authors have revised their claim in the recent version of their paper published on arXiv [66].

Li et al. [36] introduce 3DFed , a multifaceted backdoor attack composed of three elements: Constrain Loss, Noise Masks, and Decoy Model. Among these, the Constrain Loss component is crafted to target FLAME. However, it solely aims to counteract the Clipping defense facet of FLAME, as outlined in §VI of [36]. This implies that the authors did not account for the Clustering and Noising elements intrinsic to our defense design. At its core, 3DFed seeks to limit the loss during the backdoor model training phase, striving to keep the backdoor objective closely aligned with the global model in terms of L2-norm (Euclidean distance). This alignment is achieved by manipulating the hyper-parameter β𝛽\beta, meaning 3DFed ’s goal is to ensure the L2-norm of the backdoor model falls under the L2-norm-based clipping threshold. In [36], however, the authors neither discuss nor assess how hyper-parameter β𝛽\beta could be selected to ensure L2-norms of backdoored models fall below our dynamic Clipping boundary. It is important to note that because the Clipping threshold in FLAME is dynamically recalculated with each federated training iteration, it’s highly unlikely that a particular β𝛽\beta value can ensure the L2-norms of tampered models stay below our dynamic Clipping threshold while still maintaining the attack’s effectiveness. This is particularly true once Gaussian noise is factored in. As we highlighted in Section 4, we are aware of such tampered models, working on the assumption that an adversary can carefully manipulate the training process (see Constrain-and-scale attack [9]). Consequently, we argue that 3DFed cannot counteract FLAME. To empirically support this argument, we have carried out a comprehensive replication study of 3DFed using the exact source code provided by the 3DFed authors [4], strictly adhering to the experimental setup detailed in the 3DFed paper [36], as described in Section H. As anticipated, contrary to the results presented in the 3DFed paper, specifically Figures 10c, 10h, and 13c [36], our results demonstrate FLAME’s effective mitigation of 3DFed attacks across all datasets used in 3DFed experiments (see Table 7).

In conclusion, Table 5 underscores the significant discrepancy between how recent attacks interpret FLAME and the actual design principles of FLAME. Importantly, none of these approaches consider the Adaptive Noising defense, which plays a crucial role in eliminating remaining backdoor updates. This highlights the essentiality of comprehending design principles when devising an attack against FLAME.

11 Conclusion

In this paper, we introduce FLAME, a resilient aggregation framework for FL that eliminates the impact of backdoor attacks while maintaining the performance of the aggregated model on the main task. We propose a method to approximate the amount of noise that needs to be injected into the global model to neutralize backdoors. Furthermore, in combination with our dynamic clustering and adaptive clipping, FLAME can significantly reduce the noise scale for backdoor removal and thus preserve the benign performance of the global model. In addition, we design, implement, and benchmark efficient secure two-party computation protocols for FLAME to ensure the privacy of clients’ training data and to impede inference attacks on client updates.

Appendix A Datasets and Learning Configurations

Word Prediction (WP). We use the Reddit dataset of November 2017 [2] with the same settings as state-of-the-art works [9, 42, 44] for comparability. In particular, each user in the dataset with at least 150 posts and not more than 500 posts is considered as a client. This results in 80 000 clients’ datasets with sizes between 298 and 32 660 words.

The model consists of two LSTM layers and a linear output layer [9, 42]. To be comparable to the attack setting in [9], we evaluate FLAME on five different backdoors, each with a different trigger sentence corresponding to a chosen output.

Image Classification (IC). For image classification, we use mainly the CIFAR-10 dataset [34], a standard benchmark dataset for image classification, in particular for FL [42] and backdoor attacks [9, 10, 46]. It consists of 60 000 images of 10 different classes. The adversary aims at changing the predicted label of one class of images to another class of images. We use a lightweight version of the ResNet18 model [29] with 4 convolutional layers with max-pooling and batch normalization [9]. The experimental setup consists of 100 clients and uses a PMR of 20%percent2020\%. In addition to the CIFAR-10 dataset, we also evaluate FLAME’s effectiveness on two further datasets for image classification. The MNIST dataset consists of 70 000 handwritten digits [35]. The learning task is to classify images to identify digits. The adversary poisons the model by mislabeling labels of digit images before using it for training [56]. We use a convolutional neural network (CNN) with 431000 parameters. The Tiny-ImageNet 333https://tiny-imagenet.herokuapp.com consists of 200 classes and each class has 500 training images, 50 validation images, and 50 test images. We used ResNet18 [29] model.

Network Intrusion Detection System (NIDS). We test backdoor attacks on IoT anomaly-based intrusion detection systems that often represent critical security applications [7, 30, 18, 60, 33, 48, 50]. Here, the adversary aims at causing incorrect classification of anomalous traffic patterns, e.g., generated by IoT malware, as benign patterns. Based on the FL anomaly detection system DÏoT  [48], we use three datasets called DIoT-Benign, DIoT-Attack, and UNSW-Benign [48, 58] from real-world home and office deployments (four homes and two offices located in Germany and Australia). DIoT-Attack contains the traffic of 5 anomalously behaving IoT devices, infected by the Mirai malware [48]. Moreover, we collected a fourth IoT dataset containing communication data from 24 typical IoT devices (including IP cameras and power plugs) in three different smart home settings and an office setting. Following [48], we extracted device-type-specific datasets capturing the devices’ communication behavior. We simulate the FL setup by splitting each device type’s dataset among several clients (from 20 to 200). Each client has a training dataset corresponding to three hours of traffic measurements containing samples of roughly 2 000-3 000 communication packets. The learning model consists of 2 GRU layers and a fully connected layer.

Appendix B Effectiveness of FLAME’s Components

B.1 Effectiveness of the Clustering Component

We show the results for the clustering component in Tab. 6. As shown there, our filtering achieves 𝑇𝑁𝑅=100%𝑇𝑁𝑅percent100\mbox{$\mathit{TNR}$}=100\% for the Reddit and IoT-Traffic datasets, i.e., FLAME only selects benign models in this attack setting. Recall that the goal of clustering is to filter out the poisoned models with high attack impact, i.e., not necessarily all poisoned models (cf. §4.1). This allows FLAME to defend backdoor attacks effectively, even if not all poisoned models are filtered. For example, although for the CIFAR-10 dataset in Tab. 6 the TNR is not 100 % (86.2%percent86.286.2\%), the attack is still mitigated by the noising component, such that the BA is 0 % (cf. Tab. 3).

B.2 Effectiveness of Clipping

Fig. 11 demonstrates the effectiveness of FLAME’s dynamic clipping where S is the median of L2-norms compared to a static clipping bound [9] and different choices for a dynamic clipping boundary (i.e., median, half of median, median multiplied by 1.51.51.5). The experiments are conducted for the IoT-Traffic dataset, which is non-iid. Fig. 11a and Fig. 11b show that a small static bound S=0.5𝑆0.5S=0.5 is effective to mitigate the attack (𝐵𝐴=0%𝐵𝐴percent0\mbox{$\mathit{BA}$}=0\%), but 𝑀𝐴𝑀𝐴\mathit{MA} drops to 0%percent00\% rendering the model useless. Moreover, a higher static bound like S=10𝑆10S=10 is ineffective as 𝐵𝐴=100%𝐵𝐴percent100\mbox{$\mathit{BA}$}=100\% if the Poisoned Data Rate (𝑃𝐷𝑅𝑃𝐷𝑅\mathit{PDR}) ≥35%absentpercent35\geq 35\%. In contrast, FLAME’s dynamic clipping threshold performs significantly better as 𝐵𝐴𝐵𝐴\mathit{BA} consistently remains at 0%percent00\% while 𝑀𝐴𝑀𝐴\mathit{MA} remains high (cf. Fig. 11c and Fig. 11d).

B.3 Effectiveness of Adding Noise

Fig. 12 shows the impact of adding noise to the intermediate global models with respect to different noise level factors λ𝜆\lambda to determine the standard deviation of the noise σ𝜎\sigma dynamically based on the median L2-norm of the updates Stsubscript𝑆𝑡S_{t} as σ=λ​St𝜎𝜆subscript𝑆𝑡\sigma=\lambda S_{t}. As it can be seen, increasing λ𝜆\lambda reduces the 𝐵𝐴𝐵𝐴\mathit{BA}, but it also negatively impacts the performance of the model in the main task (𝑀𝐴𝑀𝐴\mathit{MA}). Therefore, the noise level must be dynamically tuned and combined with the other defense components to optimize the overall success of the defense. The noise level factor is determined by λ=1ϵ​2​l​n​1.25δ𝜆1italic-ϵ2𝑙𝑛1.25𝛿\lambda=\frac{1}{\epsilon}\sqrt{2ln\frac{1.25}{\delta}} for (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta)-DP. We use standard DP parameters and set ϵ=3705italic-ϵ3705\epsilon=3705 for IC, ϵ=395italic-ϵ395\epsilon=395 for the NIDS and ϵ=4191italic-ϵ4191\epsilon=4191 for the NLP scenario. Accordingly, λ=0.001𝜆0.001\lambda=0.001 for IC and NLP, and λ=0.01𝜆0.01\lambda=0.01 for the NIDS scenario. The DP budget is dependent on the considered dataset scenario. It is determined based on the median of the dataset sizes of the clients and the size of the model used. It can thus be empirically determined by the aggregator. Analogous to determining the clipping boundary S (cf. 4.3.2), using the median ensures that the used dataset size is within the range of benign values.

Appendix C Naïve Combination

Furthermore, we test a naïve combination of the defense components by stacking clipping and adding noise (using a fixed clipping bound of 1.0 and a standard deviation of 0.01 as in [9]) on top of a clustering component using K-means. However, this naïve approach still allows a 𝐵𝐴𝐵𝐴\mathit{BA} of 51.9% and a 𝑀𝐴𝑀𝐴\mathit{MA} of 60.24%, compared to a 𝐵𝐴𝐵𝐴\mathit{BA} of 0.0% and a 𝑀𝐴𝑀𝐴\mathit{MA} of 89.87% of FLAME in the same scenario for the CIFAR-10 dataset. Based on our evaluations in §3, it becomes apparent that FLAME’s dynamic nature goes beyond previously proposed defenses that consist of static baseline ideas, which FLAME significantly optimizes, extends, and automates to offer a comprehensive dynamic and private defense against sophisticated backdoor attacks.

Appendix D Overhead of FLAME

We evaluated FLAME for 6 different device types from the IoT dataset. In this experiment, only benign clients participated and the model was randomly initialized. The highest observed overhead was 4 additional rounds. In average, 1.671.671.67 additional training rounds were needed to achieve at least 99% of the 𝑀𝐴𝑀𝐴\mathit{MA} that was achieved without applying the defense, i.e., FLAME does not prevent the model from converging.

Appendix E HDBSCAN

HDBSCAN [13] is a density-based clustering technique that classifies data samples in different clusters without predefined the maximum distance and the number of clusters. In the following, we describe HDBSCAN in detail, following the implementation of McInnes et al.  [40, 41]. However, we focus on the behavior of HDBSCAN for the parameters that FLAME uses, i.e., when min_cluster_size=N/2+1𝑁21\nicefrac{{N}}{{2}}+1 and min_samples=1, e.g., because of the choice for min_cluster_size we skip parts that deal with multiple clusters. HDBSCAN first uses the given distances to build a minimal spanning tree (MST), where the vertices represent the individual data points and the edges are weighted by the distances between the respective points. Then it uses the MST to build a binary tree where the leaf nodes represent the vertices of the MST and the non-leaf nodes represent the edges of the MST. For this, first, all vertices are considered as separate trees (of size 1). For this, first, all vertices are considered as separate trees (of size 1) and then, starting from the edge with the lowest weight, iteratively the trees are merged by creating a non-leaf-node for each edge of the MST and set the (previously not connected) subtrees containing the endpoints of the edge as children for the new node (represented by calling the function make_binary_tree. In the next step, HDBSCAN collects all nodes of the binary tree as candidates, that cover at least N/2+1𝑁21\nicefrac{{N}}{{2}}+1 data points. Since only non-leaf nodes fulfill the requirement of covering at least N/2+1𝑁21\nicefrac{{N}}{{2}}+1 data points, each cluster candidate is based on a node, representing an edge in the MST. It uses the weight of the edge and the number of covered points to calculate a so-called stability value. Then HDBSCAN uses the stability value to determine the cluster candidate with the most homogeneous density and returns this candidate as majority cluster. Finally, it assigns the cluster label to all data points inside this cluster and labels all points outside of this cluster as noise.

Appendix F Effectiveness of FLAME against untargeted poisoning attacks

Another attack type related to backdooring is untargeted poisoning [22, 11, 10]. Unlike backdoor attacks that aim to incorporate specific backdoor functionalities, untargeted poisoning aims at rendering the model unusable. The adversary uses crafted local models with low Main Task Accuracy to damage the global model G𝐺G. Fang at el.[22] propose such an attack bypassing state-of-the-art defenses. Although we do not focus on untargeted poisoning, our approach intuitively defends it since, in principle, this attack also trade-offs attack impact against stealthiness. To evaluate the effectiveness of FLAME against this attack, we test the Krum-based attack proposed by [22] on FLAME. Since [22]’s evaluation uses image datasets, we evaluate FLAME’s resilience against it with CIFAR-10. The evaluation results show that although the attack significantly damages the model by reducing 𝑀𝐴𝑀𝐴\mathit{MA} from 92.16%percent92.1692.16\% to 46.72%percent46.7246.72\%, FLAME can successfully defend against it and 𝑀𝐴𝑀𝐴\mathit{MA} remains at 91.31%percent91.3191.31\%.

Appendix G Performance of Private FLAME

For our implementation, we use the STPC framework ABY [16] which implements the three sharing types, including state-of-the-art optimizations and flexible conversions and the open-source privacy-preserving DBSCAN by Bozdemir et al. [12]. All STPC results are averaged over 10 experiments and run on two separate servers with Intel Core i9-7960X CPUs with 2.8 GHz and 128 GB RAM connected over a 10 Gbit/s LAN with 0.2 ms RTT.

Approximating HDBSCAN by DBSCAN. We measure the effect of approximating HDBSCAN by DBSCAN including the binary search for the neighborhood parameter ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon. The results show that our approximation has a negligible loss of accuracy. For some applications, the approximation even performs slightly better than the standard FLAME, e.g., for CIFAR-10, private FLAME correctly filters all poisoned models, while standard FLAME accepts a small number (𝑇𝑁𝑅=86.2%𝑇𝑁𝑅percent86.2\mbox{$\mathit{TNR}$}=86.2\%), which is still sufficient to achieve 𝐵𝐴=0.0%𝐵𝐴percent0.0\mbox{$\mathit{BA}$}=0.0\%.

Runtime of Private FLAME. We evaluate the runtime in seconds per training iteration of the cosine distance, Euclidean distance + clipping + model aggregation, and clustering steps of Alg. 1 in standard (without STPC) and in private FLAME (with STPC). The results show that private FLAME causes a significant overhead on the runtime by a factor of up to three orders of magnitude compared to the standard (non-private) FLAME. However, even if we consider the largest model (Reddit) with K=100𝐾100K=100 clients, we have a total server-side runtime of 22 081.65 seconds (≈\approx 6 hours) for a training iteration with STPC. Such runtime overhead would be acceptable to maintain privacy, especially since mobile phones, which would be a typical type of clients in FL [42], are not always available and connected so that there will be delays in synchronizing clients’ model updates in FL. These delays can then also be used to run STPC. Furthermore, achieving provable privacy by using STPC may even motivate more clients to contribute to FL in the first place and provide more data.

Appendix H Replication Study of 3DFed

To ensure consistency with 3DFed work, we used the exact source code provided by 3DFed authors [4] and thoroughly followed the experimental setup described in 3DFed paper [36]. Every aspect, from hyper-parameter selection to training regime configuration, was carefully implemented. We repeated each experiment a minimum of 50 times to ensure robustness and reliability. To introduce variability, we employed various random seed values in each experiment. This rigorous process was applied to four distinct pre-trained models, each reaching different convergence levels based on the number of training epochs. Our experimental results, summarized in Tab. 7, primarily focus on two key metrics: Backdoor Accuracy (BA) and Main-task Accuracy (MA). The findings undeniably establish the effectiveness of Flame in mitigating 3DFed attacks. As the global model approaches convergence, a significant reduction in BA is observed, indicating that the BA closely resemble those obtained through random guesses.
